entry.title: Battery Management System for an xEV - PartÂ 1
entry.summary: This post is about information gathered on designing a BMS for a xEV
entry.content:
This is part 1 of a series on Battery management systemÂ design.

The data presented here was collected as a part of study based Internship at Kaynes Technology,Â Mysore.

Most of the data here is my notes on the followingÂ resources:

  • â€œBattery Management Systems, Volume I & IIâ€ by Gregory L. Plett along with hisÂ course.
  • â€œAdvances in Battery Technologies for Electric Vehiclesâ€ (Woodhead Publishing Series in Energy: NumberÂ 80)
  • â€œELECTRIC VEHICLE BATTERY SYSTEMSâ€ by SandeepÂ Dhameja
  • â€œBattery Reference Bookâ€ 3e by T.RÂ Crompton.

Basic terminologiesÂ¶

  • Batteries and battery packs are made up from groups of cells wired in series, parallel or a combination ofÂ them.
  • Nominal Voltage is a representative voltage that depends on the combination of the active chamicals used. It dosent relate to the voltage under load, its more of an average or typicalÂ voltage.
  • C rate is a relative measure of the cell electrical current eg. A 20 Ah cell should be able to deliver 20 A (â€œ1Câ€) for 1 h or 2 A (â€œC/10â€) for about 10 h (but, the relationship is not strictlyÂ linear)
  • A cell stores energy in electrochemical form, which it can later release to do work, The energy release rate is the cellâ€™s instantaneous power (mW, W, orÂ kW)
  • xEVs: Electric vehicles come in different categories and are abbreviated asÂ xEVs
  • Hybrid-electric vehicles (HEVs) These vehicles have drive provided by an electric motor and one other source ( like petrol engine ). The battery pack in these systems store small amount of energy and are used only for power boost when the vehicle must accelerate, or as a power sink when the vehicle must decelerate. They essentially have zero all-electric vehicle range and are never plugged in to recharge their battery pack; instead, the gasoline engine recharges the battery when extra power is available. An example HEV is the ToyotaÂ Prius.
  • Plug-in hybrid-electric vehicles (PHEVs). These vehicles are similar to HEVs but have a somewhat larger battery pack and motor. They can operate in electric-only mode under some operating conditions, typically at lower speeds such as for residential or cityÂ driving
  • Extended-Range Electric Vehicle (E-REV): Larger battery than PHEV allows some all-electric range under full-loadÂ conditions.
  • Electric Vehicle (EV), a.k.a. Battery-Electric Vehicle (BEV): Battery provides only motiveÂ power.

What must a BMS do?Â¶

The primary functions of a BMS areÂ to:

  • Protect human safety of deviceâ€™sÂ operator:
  • Detect unsafe operating conditions andÂ respond
  • Protect cells of battery from damage in abuse/failureÂ cases
  • Prolong life of battery (normal operatingÂ cases)
  • Maintain battery in a state in which it can fulfil its functional designÂ requirements
  • Inform the application controller how to make the best use of the pack right now (e.g., by providing power limits), control charger,Â etc.

Basic working of an electrochemical cellÂ¶

The function of the negative electrodeÂ¶

In an electrochemical cell, the negative electrode is often a metal or an alloy or hydrogen (lead metal or paste forÂ PbA)

  • During discharge, it gives up electrons to external circuit, is oxidized (OIL)
  • During charge, accepts electrons from external circuit, isÂ reduced

The function of the positive electrodeÂ¶

In an electrochemical cell, the positive electrode is often a metallic oxide, sulfide, or oxygen (lead oxide forÂ PbA)

  • During discharge, accepts electrons from circuit, isÂ reduced
  • During charge, gives up electrons to external circuit, isÂ oxidized

Li-ion working (The process of intercalation)Â¶

DischargeÂ process:

  • During discharge, Li exits the surface of the negative-electrode particles, gives up an electron, becoming Li in theÂ electrolyte
  • Li diffuses outward from center of negative-electrode particles to equalize concentrations, replenishing Li at particle surface (overÂ time)
  • Meanwhile, electron travels through external circuit to positiveÂ electrode
  • Li joins with the electron, and Li enters positive-electrode particles at theirÂ surface
  • Li diffuses into positive-electrode particles to equalize concentration (overÂ time)

The active electrode materials are coated on both sides of metallic foils which act as the current collectors conducting the current into and out of theÂ cell

Negative electrodes for lithium-ion cellsÂ¶

  • Presently, essentially all commercial lithium-ion cells use some form of graphite (C6 ) for the negative-electrodeÂ material
  • Graphite has graphene layers of C6 structures that are tightly bonded These layers are loosely stacked and there is room for lithium to intercalate betweenÂ them

Alternate negative-electrode material LTOÂ¶

  • Lithium titanate oxide (Li4 Ti5 O12 , LTO) is an alternative negative-electrodeÂ material
  • Disadvantage: high open-circuit potential (making cell voltage low) Advantage: nearly indestructible â€” very longÂ life

Future negative-electrode material siliconÂ¶

  • Using graphite, one can store up to one Li per six C atoms; using silicon, one can (in principle) store four Li per every SiÂ atom!
  • Unfortunately, while volume change for a charge/discharge cycle for graphite is around 10 %, it is around 400 % forÂ silicon
  • Therefore, silicon electrodes tend to fracture quickly and have shortÂ lives
  • Possible workarounds: mix graphite with silicon, or build small forests of silicon nanowires with space in-between to allow forÂ expansion

Positive electrodes for lithium-ion cellsÂ¶

Lithium cobalt oxide (LCO)Â¶

  • In 1980, John B. Goodenough discovered that Lix CoO2 (LCO) was a viable material for lithiumÂ intercalation
  • Li intercalates between the layers of CoO6Â octahedra
  • LCO has layers, somewhat like graphite, so it is often called a â€œlayeredÂ cathodeâ€

Disadavntages:

  • Cobalt is rare, toxic, andÂ expensive;
  • Only about half its theoretic capacity is useable (â€œxâ€ can be min 0.5), else cell agesÂ rapidly

NCM (a.k.a. NMC) is a blend of Ni, Co, and Mn, which retains the layered structure, and has properties from all three constituent metals; NCA is a blend of Ni, Co, and Al (used in teslaÂ batteries)

Spinel cathodesÂ¶

  • In 1983, Goodenough and Thackery proposed LixMn2O4 (LMO) as an alternate intercalation material: Mn sits in the octahedral sites, Li in theÂ tetrahedral
  • This material has a cubic â€œspinelâ€ structure. It allows 3D diffusion (vs. 2D for layered and 1D forÂ olivine)
  • LMO is cheaper and safer than LCO, but can have short lifetime due to the manganese dissolving into the electrolyte under someÂ conditions
  • Additives can be added to help prevent this, but this â€œartâ€ is presently well guarded by tradeÂ secrets

Olivine cathodesÂ¶

  • In 1997, Goodenough proposed olivine-style phosphates as a third major category of positive-electrode material LixFePO4 (LFP) is the most common in thisÂ family
  • This material is low cost, and low toxicity, but also has low energy density due to a low open-circuit potential and low specific energy due to heaviness ofÂ Fe
  • 1D structure tends to have high resistance, which can be overcome in part by using very small particles and including conductiveÂ additives

In summaryÂ¶

  • Layered cathodes (LCO, NMC, NCA) can use only around half their theoreticÂ capacity
  • Olivine cathodes (LFP) have low voltage (and very little state information in theirÂ voltage)
  • Spinel cathodes (LMO) are inexpensive and non-toxic, but can degradeÂ rapidly

What are the primary functions of a BMS?Â¶

A BMS has the followingÂ priorities:

  • Protects safety of the operator of the host application; detects unsafe operating conditions andÂ responds
  • Protects cells of battery from damage in abuse/failureÂ cases
  • Prolongs life of battery (normal operatingÂ cases)
  • Maintains battery in a state in which it can fulfill its functional designÂ requirements
  • Informs the host-application control computer how to make the best use of the pack right now (e.g., power limits), control charger,Â etc.

1. Sensing and high-voltage controlÂ¶

Measure voltage, current,temperature; control contactor, pre-charge; ground-fault detection,thermalÂ management

2. Protection againstÂ¶

Over-charge, over-discharge, over-current, short circuit, extremeÂ temperatures

3. InterfaceÂ¶

Range estimation, communications, data recording,Â reporting

4. Performance managementÂ¶

State-of-charge (SOC) estimation,power-limit computation,balance/equalizeÂ cells

5. DiagnosticsÂ¶

Abuse detection, state-of-health (SOH) estimation, state-of-life (SOL)Â estimation

The issue of costÂ¶

There is a cost associated with battery management, so not all applications implement allÂ features

Modular design of BMSÂ¶

Design extreme 1: Parallel-cell modules (PCM) Design extreme 2: Series-cell modules (SCM)

  • A modular battery pack suggests a hierarchical masterâ€“slave BMS design asÂ well
  • One â€œslaveâ€ BMS unit is associated with each module
    • Moduleâ€™s cells welded/bolted to slave PCB, minimizing wiring and wiringÂ losses
    • Slave has electronics for voltage measurement, cellÂ balancing
  • There is then normally a single â€œmasterâ€ unit for each pack
    • Master measures pack current, controlsÂ contactors
    • Communicates with slaves via daisy-chain or starÂ architecture
    • Master/slave communication uses few (e.g. two) wiresâ€”minimizes wiring-harnessÂ nightmare

BMS slave roleÂ¶

BMS slave needsÂ to:

  • Measure voltage of every cell within theÂ module
  • Measure temperatures Ideally of every cell, but in many packs some temperatures are estimated, especially if the pack has cells inÂ parallel
  • Balance the energy stored in every cell within the module this is needed as cells have different efficiencies, self-discharge rates,Â etc.
  • Communicate this information to theÂ master
  • Is slave design reusable?
    • Often â€œyesâ€, assuming electronics flexible in terms of number of cells monitored, physical size matches different applications While electronics design may be reusable in most cases, may need to redesign PCB footprint to fit individual applications For high volumes there may be overall cost savings in developing a specific slave optimized for a givenÂ module

BMS master roleÂ¶

BMS master needsÂ to

  • Control contactors that connect battery toÂ load
  • Monitor pack current,Â isolation
  • Communicate with BMS slaves Communicate with host- applicationÂ controller
  • ControlÂ thermal-management
  • Is master design reusable?
    • More difficult than for slave designs Master needs to be more flexible; for example, Number and type of contactors it controls Types of current sensors used Ways it connects to charger, thermal managementÂ system

1a. Battery-pack sensing: VoltageÂ¶

All cell voltages are measured in a lithium-ionÂ pack

  • Indicator of relative balance ofÂ cells
  • Input to most SOC and SOH estimationÂ algorithms
  • Safety: overcharging a lithium-ion cell can lead to â€œthermal runaway,â€ so we cannot skip measuring anyÂ voltages

Some methods for analog-to-digital conversionÂ¶

At the most basic level, voltage is measured using an analog-o-digitalÂ converter

There are several common ADC architectures; forÂ example,

  • A direct-conversion or flash ADC uses a bank of comparators and fixed reference voltages, outputs code of closest reference (fast,Â expensive)
  • Successive approximation compares input to output from DAC and uses feedback to modify DAC signal, resolving input to desired accuracy (slow,Â inexpensive)
  • Delta-sigma uses oversampled 1-bit flash ADC to encode difference ( ) between approximation and input, sums ( ) differences and filters to give final high-resolution result at desired slower sample rate (veryÂ popular)
  • The resolution of an ADC is the smallest change in the input signal that can be measured; it is also the step size between consecutive ADC output codes (typically 16bit adc has a resolution ofÂ 76uV)
  • Resolution for a M bit ADC is the full scale voltage difference divided by 2 to the power ofÂ M

Accuracy of an ADCÂ¶

The accuracy of an ADC has to do with the absolute difference between the reported value and the true value:difference may be due to severalÂ sources

  • Quantization error (unmeasurable valueÂ between)
  • Offset error (constant difference between ideal and measured value over whole measurementÂ range)
  • Gain error (difference between slope of ideal and measured value over whole measurement range, expressed asÂ %)
  • Nonlinear error (deviation between actual and ideal step widths, expressed as ADCÂ counts)

ChipsetsÂ¶

Special chipsets are made to aid high-voltage BMSÂ design

  • Low-cost â€œdumbâ€ measurement chips used in modules, proximate to cells; high-cost computational processing in distant masterÂ unit
  • Special chips implement difficult task of highly accurate A2D voltage sensing with high common-mode rejection and fast response in high-EMI, high-heat, high-vibrationÂ environments
  • Can often be placed in parallel for redundant fault-tolerant designs. Multiple vendors make chipsets (e.g., Analog Devices, Maxim, TexasÂ Instruments)

Example chipset: LTC6811Â¶

example (LTC6811) designed by Analog Devices (formerly LinearÂ Technology)

  • Monitors up to 12 cells in series in a module, 100s of cells in series inÂ pack
  • Has built-in isolated communications between daisy-chainedÂ parts
  • Supports internal or external cell- equalizationÂ circuitry
  • Powered by module itself, orÂ externally
  • Measures up to five temperatures (more with some externalÂ circuitry)

Selecting a chipsetÂ¶

Points to be considered in aÂ design:

  • How many cells can each ICÂ monitor?
  • How many cells total can beÂ monitored?
  • Does it support passive/activeÂ balancing?
  • What is the measurementÂ accuracy?
  • How many temperature measurements can beÂ made?
  • How many wires to communicate from IC to IC?
  • What is chipset availability and cost, perÂ cell?

1b. Battery-pack sensing: TemperatureÂ¶

Battery cell operational characteristics and cell degradation rates are very strong functions ofÂ temperature

  • Donâ€™t charge at low temperature; control thermal management systems to keep temperature in â€œsafeâ€Â region
  • Unexpected temperature changes can indicate cell failure or impending safetyÂ concern
  • Ideally, we measure each cellâ€™s internal temperature; but, With accurate pack thermal model, can place sensors external to one or more cells per module and calibrate internalÂ temperature

Measurement devices:Â¶

  • Thermocouple (uses amplifier and ADC)
  • Thermistor (uses voltage dividerÂ circuit)

Voltage-divider + thermistorÂ example

1c. Battery-pack sensing: CurrentÂ¶

Battery pack electrical current must be measured to monitor safety, log abuse, and inform SOC and SOHÂ algorithms

UsingÂ :

  • Shunt current sensor (KelvinÂ four-wire)

  • Hall-effect currentÂ sensing

Both methods have advantages and disadvantages and both are in common use in BMSÂ today

1d: High-voltage contactor controlÂ¶

When not in use, the battery pack internal high-voltage bus is completely disconnected from the load at bothÂ terminals

  • Dis/connecting pack at both terminals requires two high-current capable relays orÂ â€œcontactorsâ€
  • A low-voltage/low-current signal activates the contactor, closing an internal switch that connects its mainÂ terminals
  • As load is often capacitive, if both contactors were closed simultaneously, enormous current would flow instantly, potentially welding the contactors closed or blowing aÂ fuse
  • So, a third â€œpre-chargeâ€ contactor isÂ used

ContactorÂ procedure:

1e. Isolation sensingÂ¶

Isolation sensing detects presence of a groundÂ fault

  • Primary concern is safety: Is it safe to touch a battery terminal and chassis ground at the sameÂ time?
  • Battery â€œshouldâ€ be completely isolated from chassis ground, so â€œshouldâ€ be noÂ problem
  • FMVSS says isolation is sufficient if less than 2 mA of current will flow when connecting chassis ground to either the positive or negative terminal of the battery pack via a directÂ short

Procedure:

For fault on lowÂ side

Isolation is deemed sufficient if Ri>Vb /0.002 or R1 >Â 500Vb

1f. Thermal controlÂ¶

Important to keep battery-pack cells at a â€œcomfortableâ€temperature to ensure safety and to extendÂ life

  • Also important to keep cells at a uniform temperature for consistent aging (also reduces need for many temperatureÂ sensors)
  • Present commercial systems use either air or liquid systems, and some reports indicate that range and life are negatively impacted by airÂ systems
  • Active heating and cooling while vehicle plugged in can extend life, shorten chargeÂ times

How can a BMS protect the user and battery pack?Â¶

BMS requirement 2: ProtectionÂ¶

BMS must provide monitoring and control toÂ protect:

  • Cells from out-of-tolerance ambient operatingÂ conditions
  • User from consequences of batteryÂ failures

High-energy storage batteries can be veryÂ dangerous:

  • If energy is released in an uncontrolled way (short circuit, physical damage), can have catastrophicÂ consequences
  • In a short circuit, hundreds of amperes can develop in microseconds; protection circuitry must act quicklyÂ state

What to protect againstÂ¶

Different applications and different cell chemistries require different degrees ofÂ protection

  • Failure in a lithium-ion cell can be very serious:Â explosion/fire
  • Protection is indispensable in automotiveÂ environment
  • Protection must address following undesirable events orÂ conditions:
  • Excessive current during charging orÂ discharging
  • ShortÂ circuit
  • Over voltage and underÂ voltage
  • High ambient temperature,Â overheating
  • Loss ofÂ isolation
  • Abuse

Overcurrent/overtemperature protectionÂ¶

When possible, fallback protection paths should beÂ implemented

  • Red = cell-manufacturer specified region where cells will most likely be subject to permanentÂ damage
  • Anywhere else â€œokayâ€ but need a margin ofÂ error
  • Generally design to limit cellâ€™s operating conditions to smaller â€œsafeâ€ region, shown here inÂ green
  • Safety devices are then specified to constrain cells to safeÂ region
  • White = safetyÂ margin

Overvoltage/overtemperature protectionÂ¶

Similar for voltageÂ limits:

But, each protection device added into main current path increases battery impedance, reducing power delivered to load Examples of protection devicesÂ include:

  • Thermal fuse: Opens contactor when the temperature exceedsÂ limit.
  • Conventional fuse: May not act quicklyÂ enough
  • Active fault detection: BMS monitoring for faultÂ conditions

Fault detection/toleranceÂ¶

  • Another aspect of protection is detecting, withstanding, and (when possible) rectifyingÂ faults
  • State-of-art BMS use processors having dual CPUs that execute the same instructions at slightly different times on different cores, then compareÂ results
  • Slaves often can detect most cell faults without intervention of the main processor
    • Cell over/under voltage, over/under temperature, redundant sensing,Â etc.
    • Serious slave faults should be able to shut pack down without using masterÂ microprocessor
  • Some more complex faults (for example isolation) must be detected by theÂ software(Algorithm)
  • The link between master and slaves must have high EMIÂ immunity

StandardsÂ¶

Different applications have different standards forÂ safety

  • Passenger cars having maximum gross vehicle mass up to 3500 kg fall under ISO26262:2011
  • Electric motorcycles fall under ISO/PAS 19695:2015 (similar to ISO26262)
  • Larger trucks over 3500 kg, such as Ford F250, 350, Chevy Silverado 2500, as well as semis, buses, etcâ€¦) fall under IEC61508
  • While these safety standards have the same goals they are different in application
    • Use different â€œsafety integrity levelsâ€ (SILs), evaluated in differentÂ ways
    • Very difficult to design to all these standards simultaneously Standards are complexâ€”require study of their own to understand how to comply most likely 40% of the code written for BMS is to ensure theseÂ standards.

3 How must a BMS interface with other system components?Â¶

3a. Communication via CAN busÂ¶

  • Control Area Network (CAN) bus is industry ISO standard foron-board vehicleÂ communications
  • Designed to provide robust communications in the very harsh automotive operating environments with high levels of electricalÂ noise
  • Two-wire serial bus designed to network intelligent sensors and actuators; can operate at two rates:
    • High speed (e.g., 1M Baud): Used for critical operations such as engine management, vehicle stability, motionÂ control
    • Low speed (e.g., 100 kBaud): Simple switching and control of lighting, windows, mirror adjustments, and instrument displaysÂ (etc.)

Format of CAN-bus packetÂ¶

The protocol defines theÂ following:

  • Method of addressing the devices connected to theÂ bus
  • Data format (theÂ â€œmessageâ€)
  • Transmission speed, priority settings, andÂ sequence
  • Error detection andÂ handling
  • ControlÂ signals

A typical packet(frame) in CAN bus looks likeÂ :

Abbreviations : SOF - Start of frame; RTR- Ready to receive; CRC - cyclic redundancy check; ACK-acknowledgementÂ bit

Data frames are transmitted sequentially over theÂ bus.

3b. Charger controlÂ¶

Battery packs are charged in twoÂ ways:

  • Random: Charge delivered in unpredictable patterns; e.g., regenerative braking and are Control by providing inverter powerÂ limits
  • Plug-in: For EV/PHEV/E-REV
    • Control charger current, voltage,Â balancing
    • Often CP/CV; more exotic methods possible (in the researchÂ phase)
    • Heating systems may be required to increase charge efficiency and to increase batteryÂ longevity

What limits fast charging?Â¶

Passenger vehicles require approximately 200â€“300 Wh /Â mile

  • For 300 mile range, 60â€“90 kWh capacity, charge in 3 min (typical petrol refill time) . requires a rate of up to 1.8 MW!
  • Domestic 15 A 110 V (US) or 1 5 kW â€œlevel 1â€ service charges pack in 40â€“60Â h
  • Domestic 30 A 220 V (US- high power sockets) or 6 6 kW â€œlevel 2â€ service charges pack in 10â€“15Â h
  • DC â€œlevel 3â€ (CHAdeMO) fast charging, 500 V, 125 A can provide up to 80 % charge in 30Â min
  • Tesla â€œlevel 3â€ fast charging for model S can provide 50 % charge in 20 min So, limit is usually the electrical service, not the batteryÂ pack

3c. Log book functionÂ¶

  • For warranty and diagnostic purposes, BMS must store a log of atypical/abuse events
    • Abuse type: out of tolerance, voltage, current,Â temperature
    • Duration and magnitude ofÂ abuse

Can also store diagnostic informationÂ regarding

  • Number of charge/discharge cyclesÂ completed
  • SOH estimates at the beginning of each driving cycle And muchÂ moreâ€¦
  • Data stored in nonvolatile (e.g., FLASH) memory and downloaded whenÂ required

3d. Range estimationÂ¶

How far can I drive before available energy is depleted? Heavily influenced by environmentalÂ factors:

  • What are the vehicleÂ characteristics?
  • How is the vehicle being drivenÂ (gently/aggressively)?
  • Are there a lot of hills, a lot ofÂ wind?
  • Is it warm or coldÂ out?
  • At present, it appears that each OEM will have their own rangeÂ algorithms

BMS requirement 4: Performance managementÂ¶

Battery applications need to know two batteryÂ quantities:

  • How much energy is available in the batteryÂ pack
  • How much power is available in the immediateÂ future

Knowing energy is most important for applications such as EV: Tells me how far I can drive Knowing power is most important for applications such as HEV: Tells me whether I can accelerate or accept brakingÂ charge

Both are important for applications such as E-REV/PHEV

Why must we estimate energy, power?Â¶

We Canâ€™t measure available energy or available power directly. Instead, must estimate theseÂ values.

  • To estimate energy, we must know (atleast) all cell states-of-charge Zk and capacitiesÂ Qk
  • To estimate power, we must know (atleast) all cell states-of-charge Zk and internal resistancesÂ Rk

But, cannot directly measure these parameters either! Therefore, must estimate SOC, SOH

Available inputs include all cell voltages, pack current, and temperatures of cells orÂ modules.

There are both good and poor methods to produce estimates: Poor methods are generally simpler to understand, code, and validate, but yield less-accurateÂ results

Impacts of a poor estimator canÂ be:

  • Abrupt corrections when voltage or current limitsÂ exceeded,
  • leading to customer perception of poor drivability,Â or
  • Overcharge or overdischarge, which damages cells,Â or
  • Compensating for uncertainty by overdesigning pack All of these have costs in dollars, weight and/orÂ volume

A good way to do SOC estimate is to implement KalmanÂ filter

Whats left to explore ?Â¶

  • Article 2: How to model cells, needed byÂ algorithms
  • Article 3: Advanced methods for SOCÂ estimation
  • Article 4: SOHÂ estimation
  • Article 5: Balancing and power-limitsÂ estimation

entry.title: Notes onÂ Superconductivity
entry.content:
[TOC] This post is my notes on Superconductivity from video lectures of Sergey Frolov on Solid State Physics and other online sites such as http://www.superconductors.org

Properties¶

  • Discoverd first in Hg at 4.2K in Liquid Helium

  • Current induced in a ring follows

    $$ I(t)=I_0e^{(-t/\tau))}$$
    and dosent change much for over 100,000 years for SC and goes to 1% of initial value in few nano seconds in a normal metal.

  • Magnetic field destroy super conductivity (so does current in the SC)

  • Magnetic Impurities lower \(T_C\) (non mag has no effect)

  • Fe Co Ni nonSC

  • CU Ag Au nonSC

  • Si becomes SC at high Pressure

  • Conventional and unconventional SC

  • most unconventional SC has C,O atoms in pervoskite structure.

  • Meissner effect is perfect expulsion of Magnetic field out of SC (except penetration depth) due to screening current

  • SC act as perfect diamagnet \(\chi=-1\) and is a defining feature of SC and not just \(\rho\)=0

  • Difference between perfect conductor and SC

  • The esseence of meissner effect is that SC alaways expels the magnetic field

  • There are three tests, that are considered the gold standard for superconductivity,

1) the drop in resistance below a critical temperature threshold,

2) replacing elements in the material with heavier isotopes to observe a corresponding drop in superconductivity temperature.

3) Meissner effect: As the material passes below the critical temperature and transitions into superconductivity, it ejects its magnetic field.

  • Heat capacity of a SC is discontinuous at \(T_C\) and crashes to 0 after \(T_C\)

  • The function is given by \(C \alpha e^{a/T}\) and is simmilar to Einstein’s model of specific heat, n coupled osscilator model.

  • [verify !] Exponents often go with gaps (semiconductor and superconductor state)

  • In the super conducting state, there is a samll energy gap arround the fermi level. With \(E_g~10x^{-4}E_F\)

  • one in 10,000 electrons participate in SC state.

  • The a in \(C \alpha e^{a/T}\) is given by \(-E_g/2\)

  • Higher \(E_g\) implies higher \(T_C\)

  • Nb has the higest gap of all the materials.

Applications¶

  • Super conducting single photon detector telescope
  • Quantum computer with photons.
  • Levitating high speed trains(~600 km/h): Transport vehicles such as trains can be made to “float” on strong superconducting magnets, virtually eliminating friction between the train and its tracks.This reduces the heat generated and size occupied as compared to regular electromagnet. A landmark for the commercial use of MAGLEV technology occurred in 1990 when it gained the status of a nationally-funded project in Japan. The Minister of Transport authorised construction of the Yamanashi Maglev Test Line which opened on April 3, 1997. In April 2015, the MLX01 test vehicle attained an incredible speed of 603 kph.
  • MRI: By impinging a strong superconductor-derived magnetic field into the body, hydrogen atoms that exist in the body’s water and fat molecules are forced to accept energy from the magnetic field. They then release this energy at a frequency that can be detected and displayed graphically by a computer.
  • NMR,
  • SQUID (Superconducting QUantum Interference Device): SQUID’s are capable of sensing a change in a magnetic field over a billion times weaker than the force that moves the needle on a compass (compass: 5e-5T, SQUID: e-14T.). With this technology, the body can be probed to certain depths without the need for the strong magnetic fields associated with MRI’s. SQUIDS are being used by the U.S. NAVY to detect mines and submarines.
  • High efficiency generators: Electric generators made with superconducting wire are far more efficient than conventional generators wound with copper wire. In fact, their efficiency is above 99% and their size about half that of conventional generators.
  • Essen, Germany has the world’s longest superconducting power cable in production at 1 kilometer. It is a 10 kV liquid nitrogen cooled cable. The cable is smaller than an equivalent 110 kV regular cable and the lower voltage has the additional benefit of smaller transformers.

Superfluidity of He¶

  • Zero viscocity

  • Measurement show the 0 resistance to flow of He

  • ie the flow velocity of liquid helium is independent of applied pressure.

  • in semicunductor attraction between \(e^-\) in conduction band and holes in valence bond give rise to a bound pairs known as excitons , they also show super fluidity.

  • Because they contain real bound pairs of 2 fermions (in contrast to cooper pais) excitons are bosons.

  • as a result it is possible for them to form a Bose-Einstein condensate, a superfluid that can flow withoutt resistance
  • (this does not give rise to superconductivity as excitons are incharged

Why is there superconductivity?¶

tldr: Two electrons form a bound state called Cooper pair. These cooper pairs form a condensate.

When an electron is moving through a solid with momentum K, since it also interacts with the lattice, there is an electron phonon interaction, meaning an electron moving through the crystal launches a phonon, another electron flying in a different direction can absorb this photon and form a bound state. These cooper pairs form a condensate (they are all in the same indistinguishable quantum state). And the condensate can be represented by the wave function \(\psi=n_s e^{i \phi}\), where \(n_s\) is the density of Cooper pair and \(\phi\) denotes the phase.

London equations¶

The London equations, developed by brothers Fritz and Heinz London in 1935 relate current to electromagnetic fields in and around a superconductor.

  • In ohms law \(j=\sigma E\) so its differential wrt time is 0, however 1st london equation gives a non 0 relation with \(j'\) and \(E\) .

  • In leq1, \(j\) is the superconducting current density, E and B are respectively the electric and magnetic fields within the superconductor, \(q\) is the charge of an electron & proton, m, is electron mass, and \(n_s\), is a phenomenological constant loosely associated with a number density of superconducting carriers.

  • London eqn 1 (le1) also means that particles in a super conductor accelerate when a voltage is applied, in normal metals they only move with drift velocity and 0 acceleration.

  • taking curl on both side of le1 and using Maxwell equations you get the second form of le1. This when integrated over an area, you get the le2.

  • The rationale for the le1 can be thought of in the following different ways:

1) By definition, the electrons in a superconductor flow with no resistance, hence one can imagine electrons as if they were free electrons und er the influence of a uniform external electric field. According to the Lorentz force law \(F=eE+ev\mathrm{x}B\) these electrons should encounter a uniform force, and thus they should in fact accelerate uniformly. This is precisely what the first London equation states.

2) Current density is defined according to the equation \(j=-n_s e v\) , Taking this expression from a classical description to a quantum mechanical one, we must replace values j and v by the expectation values of their operators. The velocity operator \( v = (p+eA)/m\) is defined by dividing the gauge-invariant, kinematic momentum operator by the particle mass m. we are using as the electron charge. We may then make this replacement in the equation above. However, an important assumption from the microscopic theory of superconductivity (BCS) is that the superconducting state of a system is the ground state, and according to a theorem of Bloch’s,[] in such a state the canonical momentum p is zero. This gives us \(j=-\frac{n_s e^2}{m}\textbf{A}\) which is loosely the le1

  • The solution for that differential equation is \({ \nabla ^{2}\mathbf {B} ={\frac {1}{\lambda ^{2}}}\mathbf {B} ,\qquad \lambda \equiv {\sqrt {\frac {m}{\mu _{0}n_{s}e^{2}}}}.}\)

Superconductivity in the bulk : Cooper pairs¶

  • electron-phonon interaction leads to an attraction of electrons

  • Cooper pairs: bound states of two electrons with opposite momentum and spin.

  • size of cooper pair is characterised by coherence length $\xi = \frac{\hbar v_F}{\pi \Delta} $ electrons greater than this length cant form pairs

  • the net spin is zero so they obey Bose-Einstein statistics: at low T all pairs condense in the lowest state (no Pauli exclusion !) and hence they are Bosons

  • The gap in the diagram is the Superconducting energy gap, X-axis is the energy, 0 is the fremi level.

  • Here, the size of the energy gap indicates the energy gain for two electrons upon formation of a Cooper pair

  • If a conventional superconducting material is cooled from its metallic state (at higher temperatures) into the superconducting state, then the superconducting energy gap is absent above the critical temperature \(T_{c}\), it starts to open upon entering the superconducting state at \(T_{c}\), and it grows upon further cooling.

  • In the \Delta$ there are only cooper pair condensate and outside there are only unbound electrons.

  • BCS theory predicts that the size \(\Delta\) of the superconducting energy gap for conventional superconductors at zero temperature scales with their critical temperature \(\Delta (T=0)=1.764\,k_{B}T_{c}\) .

  • The density of states is \(N_s(E)=N_N(E) E/(E^2- D^2)^{0.5}\)

  • The super conducting state can be describes with a singel macroscopic wave function \(\Psi=\sqrt(n_s)e^{i \phi}\) with\(n_s\) is the density of the cooper pairs, \(\phi\) phase of the condensate.

  • So how does the electron pairing occur? consider the crude model:

  • in the above picture, \(\omega_D\) is the Debye relaxation time

  • Spin singlet nature of cooper pairs were confirmed with NMR measurements

  • Ferromagnetic materials are not super conduction since they cant support pairs of electrons with opposite spins (Explained by BCS)

Superconductor terminology¶

The following content on superconductor terminology is largely derived from Â http://www.superconductors.org/terms.htmÂ with some modifications.

  • Anneal: To heat and then slowly cool a material to reduce brittleness. Annealing of ceramic superconductors usually follows sintering and is done in an oxygen-rich atmosphere to restore oxygen lost during sintering. The oxygen content of a ceramic superconductor is critical. For example, YBCO with 6.4 atoms of oxygen will not superconduct. But YBCO with 6.5 atoms will.

  • Anti-ferromagnetism: A state of matter where adjacent ions in a material are aligned in opposite or “anti-parallel” arrays. Such materials display almost no response to an external magnetic field at low temperatures and only a weak attaction at higher temperatures. There is evidence that anti-ferromagnetism in the copper oxides plays a role in the formation of Cooper pairs and, thus, in facilitating a superconductive state in some compounds.

  • BCS Theory: The first widely-accepted theory to explain superconductivity put forth in 1957 by John Bardeen, Leon Cooper, and John Schreiffer. The theory asserts that, as electrons pass through a crystal lattice, the lattice deforms inward towards the electrons generating sound packets known as “phonons”. These phonons produce a trough of positive charge in the area of deformation that assists subsequent electrons in passing through the same region in a process known as phonon-mediated coupling. This is analogous to rolling a bowling ball up the middle of a bed. 2 people, one lying on each side of the bed, will tend to roll toward the center of the bed, once the ball has created a depression in the mattress. And, a 2nd bowling ball, placed at the foot of the bed, will now, quite easily, roll toward the middle.

  • Borocarbides: Superconducting borocarbides are compounds containing both boron and carbon in combination with rare-earth and transition elements; some of which exhibit the unusual ability to return to a normal, non-superconductive state at temperatures below Tc.

  • BSCCO: An acronym for a ceramic superconductor system containing the elements Bismuth, Strontium, Calcium, Copper and Oxygen. Typically, a small amount of lead is also included in these compounds to promote the highest possible Tc. BSCCO has probably found the widest acceptance among high-Tc superconductor applications due to its unique properties. BSCCO compounds exhibit both an intrinsic Josephson effect and anisotropic (directional) behavior.

  • Ceramics: Ceramic superconductors are inorganic compounds formed by reacting a metal with oxygen, nitrogen, carbon or silicon. The best-known of these are the copper-perovskites. Ceramics are typically hard, brittle, heat-resistant materials formed by a process known as solid-state reaction.

  • Charge Reservoirs: In superconductors, charge reservoirs are the layers that may control the oxidation state of adjacent superconducting planes (even though they themselves are not superconducting). In the layered cuprates, these consist of copper-oxide chains.
